body: A very small distance separated 2-year-old Soribel Batista from death -- a millimeter, no more. The toddler, who was shot in the face Friday afternoon by a bullet the police believe was intended for a drug dealer in Brooklyn, not only survived, but the bullet stopped just short of lodging in her brain. Doctors who operated on her for more than
title: A Very Close Call for Wounded Girl

body: Ligia Martinez spends her nights gripped by insomnia, in a room she shares with four others. She lies next to her daughter on a mattress, next to the small, stained mattress where her son sleeps. Her cousin's young children sleep on a bunk bed that dominates the tiny room. Getting up in the morning is hard for Ms. Martinez, not only because she has
title: The Neediest Cases; A Rootless Mother Struggles With Mental Illness

body: The New York State court system announced new rules yesterday aimed at ending patronage appointments of politically connected lawyers to safeguard estates, mismanaged businesses and property. Court officials say patronage in fiduciary appointments has led to widespread corruption. The rules were released almost three years after a bizarre letter
title: New Court Rules Address Patronage in Appointments

body: Linnette Garcia said a quick prayer, turned the doorknob and stepped slowly into the place where life had taken her. Inside a dark, cold room, her five children clinging to one another in a line behind her, Mrs. Garcia flipped a light switch, sending two large rats scurrying across a littered floor. Still, there were four walls and five beds. And
title: The Neediest Cases; An Apartment, and a Step Toward a Home

body: Sixty people were indicted yesterday on drug trafficking charges after a six-month investigation led to the breakup of five gangs that prosecutors said terrorized a Brooklyn housing development. The initial arrests took place at the Cypress Hills housing complex in late September. The investigation also led police to make arrests in Fulton County,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 60 Indicted In Drug Case

body: The five gangs sharing 30 acres of turf got along splendidly. For at least the last five years, the police say, ''The Rough Riders,'' ''The Little A-Team,'' ''The Front Crew'' and the other gangs agreed to d√©tente. Business was thriving in each little slice of the sprawling Cypress Hills housing complex in Brooklyn, and there was little need to
title: Drug-Gang Arrests Seen as Positive Step at Brooklyn Complex

body: Five separate drug gangs that operated like a trade association within a sprawling Brooklyn housing development were dismantled this week after a six-month investigation, the authorities announced yesterday. Investigators arrested 45 people, including eight high-level leaders who together put a stranglehold on residents of the Cypress Hills
title: 45 Arrested in Assault on 5 Brooklyn Drug Gangs

body: Two men were arrested yesterday in the beating death of a man who accidentally walked into the middle of a neighborhood dispute, the police said. The two men -- Rafael Santos, 27, of the Bronx, and Hardy Marston, 18, of Queens -- were charged with murder, assault and criminal possession of a weapon, the police said. The victim, Mizanor Rahman, 37,
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: 2 Arrested In Sunday Beating Death

body: A Brooklyn man on his way home from work was clubbed to death late Sunday by a group of men who apparently mistook him for someone one of them had quarreled with a few hours earlier, the authorities said yesterday. The victim, Mizanor Rahman, 37, a waiter at a Battery Park City restaurant, was walking from the Grant Avenue subway station at 11:50
title: Man Beaten to Death in Case Of Apparent Mistaken Identity

body: IN 1987, at 19, an accident left Russell Hopkins of Bushwick, Brooklyn, a quadriplegic. Strapped to an electric wheelchair twice his weight, he was no longer able to execute perfect back flips to impress the girls. There were no more Michael Jackson-like dance moves to perform for home videos. There were no more giant bear hugs for a laughing but
title: Living Large In a Small Room

body: In the 10 years since she was first elected to the State Senate, Nellie Santiago has never faced an election without a Democratic primary challenge. Still, Ms. Santiago, who represents Bushwick and Cypress Hills in Brooklyn, has typically won easily with wide margins over little-known opponents. Coasting to victory this year is shaping up to be a
title: After Easy Victories, Brooklyn State Senator Faces a Tough Primary Battle

body: HICKEY-Lillian F. 93, on July 19, 2002. Born and lived in Brooklyn from 1909 until 1994. She had been employed as a personnel manager for General Accident Co Inc, NYC, from 1932-1974. Beloved aunt of Richard E. Hickey, Marie Breslin and Eileen Mosier, great-aunt of many, and great - great - aunt of two. Graveside service 11 AM, Monday, July 22,
title: Paid Notice: Deaths HICKEY, LILLIAN F.

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: Race for Staten Island Q. Did Staten Island really end up as part of New York because of a sailing competition? A. So the legend goes. Disputes over the boundaries separating New York and New Jersey were common in the Colonial era (and have resurfaced from time to time). So valuable were shipping revenues that in the 1680's New York's governor,
title: F.Y.I.

body: MORTON-Jane B. On July 6, 2002 at age 91. Wife of the late Paul Stillman Morton. Loving mother of Kathleen Stillman Morton and the late Jane Goldman. Grandmother of Christopher Morton Aberger and Daniel Paul Goldman. Friends may call at Frank E. Campbell, 1076 Madison Avenue at 81st St. on Friday, July 12, 5-9PM. Interment to take place Saturday,

body: After living in a two-family house in the Borough Park section of Brooklyn for 10 years, Maria and Luciano Genao, who came to the United States from the Dominican Republic, wanted a house of their own. But they had only a sketchy idea of how much they could afford and how much the down payment and closing costs would add to their purchase. They
title: Residential Real Estate; Making Ownership Easier For Lower-Income People

body: WHAT did the Collyer brothers ever do for Harlem? That's the question asked by the Harlem Fifth Avenue Block Association, which seeks to rename the tiny park at the northwest corner of 128th and Fifth Avenue. The group would like to see plaques go up with the legend Reading Tree Park, but, for the near term at least, the park will continue to
title: Streetscapes/128th St. and Fifth Ave., Former Site of the Harlem House Where the Collyer Brothers Kept All That Stuff; Wondering Whether a Park Should Keep Its Name

body: For a startlingly long while, everyone managed to get along. In the weeks and months after the terrorist attacks, as memorial services multiplied and DNA matches trickled in, many victims' families, stoic and shocked, tried to live in a grudge-free universe. Feuds were held in abeyance. Least-favorite relatives were embraced with smiles of
title: Lure of Millions Fuels 9/11 Families' Feuding

author: E-mail: fyi@nytimes.com
body: The Boss on the Run Q. Given the recent rash of suspects escaping from police custody, I'm wondering who was the city's most famous jailbird to take flight. A. Few escapees could match the fame of William M. Tweed, the boss of Tammany Hall, who went on the lam in 1875. Famously, Tweed was a former bookkeeper and volunteer fireman who was elected an
title: F.Y.I.

body: Randolph Maddix, a schizophrenic who lived at a private home for the mentally ill in Brooklyn, was often left alone to suffer seizures, his body crumpling to the floor of his squalid room. The home, Seaport Manor, is responsible for 325 starkly ill people, yet many of its workers could barely qualify for fast-food jobs. So it was no surprise that
title: For Mentally Ill, Death and Misery

body: THE subprime mortgage industry, which serves people with bad or blemished credit histories, has burgeoned in the economic boom of the last 10 years, allowing people previously deemed uncreditworthy to buy a home or to raise funds by refinancing their mortgage. But as the industry has expanded, so has its dark seam -- predatory lending. And as
title: A Wider Loan Pool Draws More Sharks

body: ATTRACTIONS AMERICAN MUSEUM OF NATURAL HISTORY'S ROSE CENTER FOR EARTH AND SPACE, Central Park West at 81st Street. This weekend, the Hayden Planetarium presents ''The Search for Life: Are We Alone?,'' which ponders the question of life beyond Earth. and the Big Bang Theater, featuring narrated visual and audio effects simulating the beginning of
title: SPARE TIMES

body: Harry Houdini, the greatest escape artist of all time, has done it again! This time from a dusty cardboard box in the back of a bedroom closet! No restraint can hold him! It might not measure up to his most thrilling feats, but considering that Houdini has been dead since 1926, this latest stunt as reported by the authorities yesterday had a lot of
title: With Police Help, a Bust of Houdini Reappears

body: Eight middle school teachers in Brooklyn, Queens and the Bronx have each received $15,000 grants to reward teaching that defies the chalk-and-talk model. Winning lessons include history classes that travel throughout the Northwest Bronx and East New York and a Brooklyn science class that uses computers to care for a student-built greenhouse. The
title: BULLETIN BOARD; Grants for Unusual Teaching

body: In the eyes of his critics, the Rev. David Benke worshiped publicly in the company of unbelievers. For that, they say, he stands guilty of heresy and idolatry. What is striking about the case is that those critics are Lutheran pastors, Pastor Benke holds a position that is the Lutheran equivalent of a bishop, and the event was the national prayer
title: Seeing Heresy In a Service For Sept. 11; Pastor Is Under Fire For Interfaith Prayers
